message_1: A differentiable function on a closed interval [a,b] has the property that the absolute value of its derivative is no greater than 1. Find the maximum possible value of the difference between the values of this function at a and b.
message_2:
Let f(x) be the differentiable function on the closed interval [a, b] with the property that |f'(x)| ≤ 1 for all x in [a, b]. We want to find the maximum possible value of |f(b) - f(a)|.

By the Mean Value Theorem, there exists a point c in the open interval (a, b) such that

f'(c) = (f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a).

Since |f'(c)| ≤ 1, we have

|(f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a)| ≤ 1.

Multiplying both sides by |b - a|, we get

|f(b) - f(a)| ≤ |b - a|.

Thus, the maximum possible value of the difference between the values of the function at a and b is |b - a|.
